The section on Phase III investigations contains a discussion on personnel management, both in terms of general staff and in terms of professional personnel
Archaeology: Theories, Methods, and Practice

Although not anthropological in orientation nor written with Americanist archaeology in mind, this is one of best overall method-and-theory texts available. It presents the various interpretive and conceptual tools required of archaeologists designing and interpreting full-scale excavations

container-title: Curating Archaeological Collections: From the Field to the Repository
note: This series, focused on North America, is a valuable reference for all archaeologists.

title: Reaching the Hidden Audience: Ten Rules for the Archaeological Writer
A Writer’s Reference
This is one of many excellent grammatical references updated periodically

container-title: Arkush. Archaeological Laboratory Methods: An Introduction
note: This text provides discussion on all aspects of basic archaeological laboratory procedure, including how to design and run a university archaeology laboratory.
title: Writing Archaeology: Analyses and Archaeological Argumentation. The SAA Archaeological Record
This short article has good general advice for archaeological writers
The Thames & Hudson Manual of Typography

In a thorough discussion of how to present text on a page, McLean considers issues of typeface readability (serif typefaces are usually best for extensive text), how text is read (people read entire words, and they read those words generally based upon the upper halves of the letters), number of words per read line (eight words or fewer is best; otherwise, the eye gets confused), and the history and structure of typefaces. This is a useful volume for the desktop publishing world
Methods and Theory in Historical Archaeology

Essential reading for anyone facing historic deposits. Perhaps dated in some way, but South originated the basic ways in which the assemblages from historic sites can be handled relative to the people—or society—that produced and then used those assemblages
Archaeological Ethics
Ethical issues frequently arise in archaeology. Some of these issues arise in the context of preparing the professional report, and they might be addressed in this collection of articles
